question: Municipal Solid Waste (MSW) is mainly generated by households, offices, and public places.
Plastic waste is biodegradable and decomposes within a few days.
Food scraps, paper, and glass are common examples of municipal solid waste.
The main source of bio-medical waste is construction sites and factories.
Used syringes and surgical instruments are considered bio-medical waste.
E-waste consists of discarded electronic devices such as laptops, mobile phones, and televisions.
Greenhouse gas emissions from decomposing waste contribute to climate change.
Plastic waste helps in improving soil fertility when dumped in open areas.
Recycling is an effective method for managing municipal solid waste.
Developed countries generate more e-waste compared to developing countries due to higher consumption of electronic devices.
E-waste contains harmful substances such as lead, mercury, and cadmium.
Incineration is the process of burying waste deep underground.
Landfilling is a method used to manage non-recyclable waste by burying it in designated areas.
Proper segregation of waste at the source helps in better waste management.
Biomedical waste includes paper waste and food waste from hospital kitchens.
The three Rs in waste management stand for Reduce, Reuse, and Recycle.
Expired medicines and chemical waste are examples of e-waste.
Improper disposal of bio-medical waste can spread diseases such as HIV and Hepatitis.
Public awareness plays an important role in reducing waste generation.
E-waste is biodegradable and decomposes within a few years.
Hazardous waste includes toxic substances like pesticides and batteries.
Old clothes and glass bottles cannot be reused and must be discarded.

Plastic waste does not contribute to the clogging of drainage systems.
E-waste should be managed through proper recycling and disposal methods.
Composting is an effective way to manage organic waste such as food scraps and vegetable peels.
Hospitals generate only a small amount of bio-medical waste per day.
Bio-medical waste should be disposed of in regular garbage bins.
Heavy metals from e-waste can contaminate soil and groundwater.
Non-biodegradable waste can be easily broken down by natural processes.
Methane, a greenhouse gas, is released from decomposing organic waste.
Recycling electronic devices can help recover valuable metals such as gold and copper.
Proper disposal of e-waste can reduce health risks associated with toxic materials.
Bio-medical waste should be segregated into different colored bins for proper disposal.
Littering in public places has no impact on the environment.
Reducing plastic usage can help minimize municipal solid waste.
Old electronic devices should be thrown in regular trash bins.
Segregation of waste helps in better recycling and waste management.
The rapid growth of technology has led to an increase in e-waste generation.
Dumping waste in open areas has no harmful impact on the environment.
Refurbishing and reusing old electronic devices is an effective way to manage e-waste.
Proper waste management helps in maintaining a cleaner and healthier environment.
Plastic bags decompose quickly in landfills.
Extended Producer Responsibility (EPR) requires companies to collect and recycle their old products.

Recycling reduces the need for raw materials and helps conserve natural resources.

Improper waste disposal can lead to serious environmental and health hazards.
Government regulations and policies play an important role in effective waste management.
